title: Between 1 July 2019 and 30 June 2020, will an armed group from the Central African Republic engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in the Central African Republic?
preds: I am increasing the probability: after reading past year resolution, I think I sort of finally understand the phrasing of the question. It does not refer to a single massacre, but the cumulative over a year.
Different factions fighting for control, issues, could come to a head by summer and close in Autumn (Southern Hemisphere)
Actually, owing to the scarcity of the information available, it's difficult to make an estimation.
Campaign as in ongoing activities of existing groups is certain, uncertainty lies in if 1000 casualties will be reached by 1 group alone.
Africa is noted as being lawless and unprotected civilians are always the target.

Both the Christian and Muslim militias seem to be in detente at the moment with a tentative peace deal in coordination. However, tensions are still high enough that a single event could derail the process. The international community's lack of interest in the country mean's that there's no bulwark to prevent a single incident from escalating; an underfunded UN effort may not be enough.

The Early Warning Project predicts a 3.7% chance of a new mass killing.  Although a tentative peace agreement was mediated by the AU,  tensions are still high and attacks are ongoing. These attacks may just be for the rebel groups to save face among their supporters,  not wanting to be viewed as weak for working with the government.  Due to the peace deal signed earlier this year (in which some rebel leaders where given government positions), it seems unlikely that rebels will carry out a systematic campaign that will leave over 1,000 dead.  Such a campaign would only serve to hurt their progress, unless it is in response to actions and policies undertaken by the government.  However,  after years of conflict with the rebels in addition to a weak economy ,  I think it is unlikely that the government  will do anything to seriously jeopardize it's improving relationship with the rebels.  I estimate 5% rather than 3.7% because Sidiki Abass, leader of my 3R and current military advisor to the Prime Minister,  is a bit of a wild card. His appointment may end up inflaming tensions in the long run.  Sources:
https://earlywarningproject.ushmm.org/countries/central-african-republic
https://www.hrw.org/news/2019/07/18/central-african-republic-armed-group-kills-46-civilians
https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2019/country-chapters/central-african-republic
https://www.cfr.org/interactive/global-conflict-tracker/conflict/violence-democratic-republic-congo
The volume of deaths is problematic. Mass killings are still likely, but will they total 1000 or more?

Since Ebola has hit Goma (main transport hub for central Africa) the Séléka will look to eradicate any sign off the disease in the "Republic of Logone, (officially Dar El Kuti)" region with mass extermination, your use an Ebola out break in the Christian areas as a justification to carry out an attack.
Very limited if any triggers for such unrest or pending political events.

Currently anti-balaka groups, which were previously carrying out the greatest number of killings, seem to be relatively quiet. The Fulani group 3R seems to be most active, but massacres carried out by 3R are relatively low. Population density is very thin, so while I think killings will happen, the numbers will probably not reach 1,000 lives in a single campaign.
